author: Todd Buell
title: ECB's Coeuré warns over Grexit-style threat - MarketWatch
text:
FRANKFURT--Europe cannot sit back and expect that cheap energy and an accommodative monetary policy alone will bring strong growth and low unemployment back to the currency bloc, said European Central Bank executive board member Benoît Coeuré in remarks published Thursday.
Mr. Coeuré said that citizens in the bloc expect unemployment to come down and growth to strengthen. "There is a temptation to leave it up to the low oil price and the ECB's accommodative monetary policy," he said in remarks prepared for delivery in Paris and published on the ECB's website.
"Monetary policy can support growth but it cannot create it in a lasting way," he said. "And the effectiveness and legitimacy of euro area governance will not be increased by placing excessive demands on the central bank--quite the opposite."
Rather, the central banker said that efforts to integrate and reduce differences among eurozone economies needed to move forward. He specifically urged that the eurozone's banking union be completed and warned of the risks from continued doubts about the euro's future.
"We must be clear, however: the euro area is an irreversible project, not simply a fixed exchange rate system," he said. "The exit of a member country would inevitably lead economic actors to wonder who would be next, with all the potential destabilizing effects that such speculation could entail."
Just last month, Greece nearly became the first country to exit the currency bloc, as negotiations between the embattled country and its creditors almost failed to reach a deal on a new bailout agreement.
"We need to use the confidence in the single currency to build institutions that will reinforce the cohesion of our economic and political union," he said.
Mr. Coeuré also said that the eurozone's permanent bailout fund, the European Stability Mechanism, could "become the foundation of a 'euro area Treasury'."
While the words of the Mr. Coeuré and the ECB on the future of the ESM certainly carry weight, a decision on the ESM lies with governments and not with the central bank.
